conclusion: Problem involves two objects A and B starting from the same location and moving in the same direction, with a graph showing their velocities over time.
Graph has time on the x-axis and velocity on the y-axis, with curves labeled A and B.
Object A starts with a high velocity and slows down, while object B starts from rest, accelerates to a peak, then decelerates.
Points where velocities are equal are marked as t1, t2, t3, and t4.
Area under a velocity-time graph represents displacement.
Difference in displacements tells how far apart objects are at a given time.
Goal is to find when the difference in displacements is maximized.
Between t=0 and t=t1, object A has a higher velocity than object B.
At t=t1, their velocities are equal.
Between t=t1 and t=t2, object B has a higher velocity than object A.
At t=t2, object A's velocity is zero, and object B is still moving.
Between t=t2 and t=t3, object A starts accelerating while object B is decelerating.
At t=t3, their velocities are equal again.
Between t=t3 and t=t4, object A has a higher velocity than object B.
At t=t4, their velocities are equal once more.
Consider cumulative displacement difference to find when they are farthest apart.
Relative velocity is the velocity of A minus the velocity of B.
Distance changes based on relative velocity.
Plotting relative velocity over time, the area under the curve gives relative displacement.
Without functions, consider areas under curves for A and B separately and find the difference.
Area under curve A from t=0 to time t is S_A(t), and for B is S_B(t).
Separation at time t is |S_A(t) - S_B(t)|.
Find time t where |S_A(t) - S_B(t)| is maximized.
